glossary.Description: The voice of a verb describes the relationship between the action (or state) that the verb expresses and the subject (agent, actor of the verb). The active voice focuses on the subject performing the action and what it does. For example, "We interviewed 50 persons." The verb "interviewed" is in the active voice.
APA stands for American Psychological Association. The APA citation style is commonly used.
This is a section of your report where you would insert documents that provide more information about your research and findings. This includes project planning and survey documents.
A bibliography lists the sources that you have referred to in your report. The bibliography is usually placed at the end of your project report.
The conclusion provides a summary of the major inferences made from the findings, an answer to the problem statement and your recommendations.
This means to quote using the exact words and punctuation from the source.
This section analyses the impact of the research findings on your problem statement. A comparison may also be made with previous research done by other researchers.
The results and findings of your research are presented in the Findings section.
E.g. "I", "we" and "you".
An impersonal style of writing that uses the passive voice and avoids personal first person pronouns.
A personal style of writing that uses the active voice and first person pronoun.
The Introduction states the purpose and scope of your research. It also provides useful background information which will familiarise the readers with your research topic and why it was chosen.
A Literature Review is a systematic review of published information about a particular topic. It includes previous research conducted by other researchers.
MLA stands for Modern Language Association. The MLA citation style is one of the more commonly used styles.
This means to express or summarise the meaning of the idea or what was said in your own words.
The passive voice focuses on the subject that is the target of the action rather than the person who performed the tasks. For example, "50 persons were interviewed."
Original research that you conducted. This is contrasted with secondary research, which gathers information from publications and other published sources.
Qualitative research is descriptive and is not quantitative. It includes peopleï¿½s opinions, reasons for their behaviour, and descriptions of events and their causes.
Research that is measurable and quantifiable. Data that can be analysed in terms of numbers.
This is a sub-section within the Conclusion section, where you recommend actions for further research or solutions to problems identified in the research.
The Research Methods section contains a detailed account of how you collected your research data.
A sample is a group of people randomly selected to represent a greater population.
Involves gathering research information from publications and other published sources.
E.g. "It", "He", "She", "They" and "The researchers".
